Identification_Area.title: PVO VENUS ION MASS SPECTROMETER CALIB HIGH RES ION DENS V1.0

Modification_Detail.description: extracted metadata from PDS3 catalog and modified to comply with PDS4 Information Model

External_Reference.reference_text: Brinton, H.C., L.R. Scott, M.W. Pharo, III, and J.T.C. Coulson, The Bennett ion-mass spectrometer on Atmosphere Explorer-C and -E, Radio Sci., vol. 8, 323, 1973.

Grebowsky, J.M., W.T. Kasprzak, R.E. Hartle, K.K. Mahajan, and T.C.G. Wagner, Superthermal Ions Detected in Venus Dayside Ionsheath, Ionopause, and Magnetic Barrier Regions, J. Geophys Res., vol. 98, no. E5, 9055, May 25, 1993.

Taylor, H.A., Jr., H.C. Brinton, S.J. Bauer, R.E. Hartle, T.M. Donahue, P.A. Cloutier, F.C. Michel, R.E. Daniell, Jr., B.H. Blackwell, Ionosphere of Venus: First observations of the dayside ion composition near dawn and dusk, Science, vol. 203, 752, 1979.

Taylor, H.A., Jr., H.C. Brinton, S.J. Bauer, R.E. Hartle, P.A. Cloutier, F.C. Michel, R.E. Daniell, Jr., T.M. Donahue, R.C. Maehl, Ionosphere of Venus: First observations of the effects of dynamics on the dayside ion composition, Science, vol. 203, 755, 1979.

Data_Set_PDS3.data_set_name: PVO VENUS ION MASS SPECTROMETER CALIB HIGH RES ION DENS V1.0
Data_Set_PDS3.data_set_terse_desc: Pioneer Venus (PVO) Ion Mass Spectrometer (OIMS) high resolution ion density data set for the period periapsis +/- 30 minutes for all 5055 orbits (1978-12-05 - 1992-10-07).
Data_Set_PDS3.data_set_desc:
Data Set Overview ================= The PV-OIMS high resolution dataset contains data from the Orbiter Ion Mass Spectrometer (OIMS) experiment and orbit attitude data for orbits 1-5055, including data for the period periapsis +/- 30 minutes for each orbit. The dataset is divided into multiple files which contain 1 orbit. The user should be able to easily get to any desired orbit by selecting the appropriate file.
Data ==== The data are provided in fixed length records (ASCII) with each record consisting of 119 data elements totaling 843 bytes. The record structure is described below. Each record represents one complete OIMS experiment data cycle (normally 6.3 seconds but this time can vary with the bit rate). Within each record there are 55 samples of mass and the density associated with that mass. The sequence of masses within a record will normally follow the OIMS ''explore'' mode, but this sequence may vary when the experiment is occasionally in the ''explore-adapt'' mode.
To compute the time associated with a particular mass and density, the dwell time element (element 5) should be used along with the time of day (element 3). The dwell time is time interval (milliseconds) between samples. Thus, for the ''Nth'' sample, the time would be computed as follows:
TIME = UT = (N - 1) * DWELL/1000 (where UT is the time of day)
The user should be aware that some of the densities have been coded. For example, the values 999 and 9.9999e+04 are the missing data values for mass and density, respectively, for that point. (This can be due to several reasons such as telemetry interference or a gap in the data occurred.) Also, a negative value of density represents a 'flagged' data point and should be used with caution.
column type bytes description ==================== ===================================== jdate int 5 date in format yyddd where dd is day of year ut float 9 seconds of day dwell int 6 time interval <milliseconds> between samples bits int 6 telemetry rate in <bits/second> lat float 7 Venus latitude <deg> lon float 8 Venus longitude <deg> alt float 10 Altitude <km> sza float 9 Solar Zenith Angle (Sun-Venus-PVO) <deg>. sha float 9 Solar Hour Angle <hour>. mass1 int 4 Mass of species number 1 <AMU>. den1 float 10 Density of species 1 <ions/cm**3>. mass2 int 4 Mass of species 2 <AMU>. den2 float 10 Density of species 2 <ions/cm**3>. . . . . . . . . . . . . mass55 int 4 Mass of species 55 <AMU>. den55 float 10 Density of species 55 <ions/cm**3>.
Data_Set_PDS3.confidence_level_note: Bad data have been excluded or flagged by using negative values for density. Users should still use caution when interpreting these data. No error estimates for the densities are provided.
